body_html:
@YunYang1994 You need to make sure the pytorch nightly you use to export the model is the same as the the libtorch you're building against. This is complicated by the fact that the name of the pytorch nightly in conda has changed from pytorch-nightly to pytorch-nightly-cpu, so installing pytorch-nightly gets you an old version.

So in summary: on the same day, do conda install pytorch-nightly-cpu -c pytorch and download libtorch from https://download.pytorch.org/libtorch/nightly/cpu/libtorch-macos-latest.zip. Then re-export the model using the new nightly you just installed.
body_text:
@YunYang1994 You need to make sure the pytorch nightly you use to export the model is the same as the the libtorch you're building against. This is complicated by the fact that the name of the pytorch nightly in conda has changed from pytorch-nightly to pytorch-nightly-cpu, so installing pytorch-nightly gets you an old version.
So in summary: on the same day, do conda install pytorch-nightly-cpu -c pytorch and download libtorch from https://download.pytorch.org/libtorch/nightly/cpu/libtorch-macos-latest.zip. Then re-export the model using the new nightly you just installed.
body:
@YunYang1994 You need to make sure the pytorch nightly you use to export the model is the same as the the libtorch you're building against. This is complicated by the fact that the name of the pytorch nightly in conda has changed from `pytorch-nightly` to `pytorch-nightly-cpu`, so installing `pytorch-nightly` gets you an old version.

So in summary: on the same day, do `conda install pytorch-nightly-cpu -c pytorch` and download libtorch from https://download.pytorch.org/libtorch/nightly/cpu/libtorch-macos-latest.zip. Then re-export the model using the new nightly you just installed.
